newsitem.title: BURUNDI: Burundi appeals for end to sanctions.
newsitem.headline: Burundi appeals for end to sanctions.

text.p: Burundi's prime minister appealed on Saturday to East African ministers meeting in Tanzania to lift sanctions imposed after a July coup on the central African country riven by ethnic violence.
A committee of East African interior ministers meeting in northern Tanzania on Saturday was expected to decide whether humanitarian aid to Burundi should be excluded from sanctions.

"My message to interior ministers is to understand Burundi and to understand the negative impact that sanctions are having on the country. This embargo isn't going to bring peace," Prime Minister Pascal Firmin Ndimira told a news conference.
Ethnic Tutsi Pierre Buyoya seized power in an army coup on July 25 and named Hutu Ndimira to head his government in an effort to display his moderate credentials.

Ndimira warned sanctions could "boomerang on neighbouring countries," increasing their responsibility if Burundi declined into an all out ethnic war like the one in neighbouring Rwanda in 1994, which killed up to one million people.
African states including Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda and Rwanda on July 31 closed their borders with Burundi and imposed stiff economic and transport sanctions on the landlocked country.
They demanded a return to constitutional government and the start of all-party talks to include the Tutsi-dominated army and Hutu rebel groups currently waging a civil war.
Buyoya left Bujumbura on Saturday for the Lake Victoria town of Musoma in Tanzania for a meeting with Burundi negotiator Julius Nyerere.
Diplomats said the main point of discussion would be a regional summit and whether Buyoya would be allowed to attend.
Ndimira outlined his plan of action this week in a 20-page speech, saying he wanted to bring peace, revive the economy and restore the state's democratic institutions.
A senior aid official said the plan was "academic and irrelevant" in the light of sanctions and continued fighting in Burundi, which has killed 150,000 people since October 1993.
European nationals living in Burundi on Saturday appealed to European Union president Jacques Santer in a letter to help end sanctions, Burundi state radio reported.
"The European nationals in Burundi underlined that there is no other country where such harsh sanctions have been imposed with so little cause," the radio said.

In Brussels on Friday, Burundi's banned Frodebu party said it was considering starting armed resistance against the military government if peaceful political pressure fails to restore democracy to the tiny central-African country.

"If the international community does not take action, if the massacres continue and if the military junta remains in power, Frodebu will have to review its principle of non-violence," Frodebu Chairman Jean Minani told a news conference.
Minani also called for a strict application of the embargo imposed on Burundi by neighbouring states.
